http://www.kurzweilai.net/fruit-fly-nervous-system-provides-new-solution-to-fundamental-computer-network-problem

This is interesting from a developmental encoding point of view,
specifically with respect to the latest hyperneat work around
placement of neurons.

My hyperneat take on this idea would be to produce a bunch of
'speculative' neurons in the substrate with varying density based on
querying the CPPN. Then place a random timer in each neuron, when a
timer fires that neuron becomes a real neuron and tells surrounding
neurons not to fire. I appreciate it puts time back into the
developmental process, which could slow things down (one of the wins
of CPPNs was the elimination of iterative developmental processes).

Regards,

Colin
